content: Click file>new>existing email account. Then enter your name and email address, but omit the password. Follow through the prompts and Google will eventually prompt for your password. If the menu bar isn't shown, click the alt key and then the File option will appear.
creator: davidsk

content: The print menu has a color option for color vs black&white and also has a tickbox for printing backgrounds. I think if you select color and tick to print backgrounds that the color will work. I tested it and it works for me.

content: Yes but then someone else can just open it again, I want to log out completely and only log in with my password to avoid other people reading my emails.
creator: joparsons26

content: You can set a primary password at settings>privacy&security. You must remember it, as there is no way to recover it if lost. The feature isn't perfect, as others could still read messages already downloaded, but there is a bug already filed to correct that. The only real safe way is to set up private accounts in Windows (if you use Windows).
creator: davidsk

content: Sorun e-posta sunucunuzdan kaynaklanıyor. E-posta hizmeti aldığınız firmaya danışmanızı öneririm.
creator: maxcoder

content: The easiest approach is the import-export NG addon. highlight the highest level (e.g, Local Folders), rightclick and select one of the export options.
creator: davidsk

content: Non hai fornito praticamente nessuna informazione sulla tua configurazione, per cui posso solo fare ipotesi. Probabilmente usi IMAP come protocollo ed accesi alla tua casella email anche da altri dispositivi. Da uno di questi hai cestinato i messaggi e Thunderbird ha semplicemente sincronizzato il proprio archivio.
creator: @next

content: - click the 'new message' button - if menu bar does not show, press alt key - from menu bar, click view>toolbars and tick 'composition toolbar' to restore the 'send' button.
creator: davidsk

content: To my knowledge, you need to use PST file, which is not simple. This is a long thread, but I think it will give you the necessary info: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1413379
creator: davidsk

content: Direttamente no. Se l'app Mail di Windows esporta le email in formato eml, o in archivi mbox, questi possono essere importarti facilmente in Thunderbird. Ma non usando Mail non saprei dirti.
creator: @next

content:
First, I have never attempted to modify headers, so my suggestions may be irrelevant. Your question interested me, so I poked around a bit: I noticed two addons that refer to headers: header tools like and header tools improved. You can also create custom headers with config editor - see https://www.lifewire.com/arbitrary-custom-heading-email-thunderbird-1173089

But I hope someone with experience jumps in to add comments.
creator: davidsk

content: True, many web pages are still incorrect for some menu names. For the config editor, there is no save command. closing the editor is sufficient. You may need to reopen it to confirm that your entry is there. Otherwise, this is beyond my experience, as I've never modified headers.
creator: davidsk

content: Are you using a portable version, or did you do the install from https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/ ? Or is it from the Microsoft store? Highlight a folder in Local Folders, rightclick and select properties. That should show you the location of the file and that should let you surmise where the full profile is.
creator: davidsk

content: I downloaded/installed Thunderbird from the Microsoft Store. Doing what you said shows C:/Users/photo/AppData/Roaming/Thunderbird/Profiles/k6i7koof.default-release/Mail/Local Folders/Family as the location. I get a "Windows can't find" error message. Following the path, once again, the "Thunderbird" folder doesn't exist under AppData/Roaming/ ... or, at least, I can't see it -- and, apparently, Windows can't either.
creator: photog2

content: See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1434631
creator: sfhowes

content: More than one way to skin the cat... I ended up doing an EXPORT of my profile on the old PC to an external hard drive, then IMPORTED it to my new PC. Voila, all my folders showed up just fine -- which is what I was trying to accomplish. Thanks sfhowes for the pointer to the other solution. It came in about the same time I was doing the import and probably would have solved the problem.
creator: photog2
